This is a good article, but it is so long it is hard to see the key issues.  I have a research lab where we do PCR (polymerase chain reaction, the core technique in the test), and have been watching the problems with the coronavirus test.  I think there are three main problems:

1.  The CDC was slow in developing its test.
2.  The CDC required testing labs to have a particular combination of very specific equipment and reagents, which few labs did.  Even minor substitutions were initially not allowed.
3.  The equipment and reagents needed in the CDC test, and also in recently-approved variants of the test, are specialized, and only available in limited quantities.

Although the number of tests is increasing, it is still being held back by these problems.  A willingness to use more commonly-available reagents would allow many more tests to be done.  However, work validating the use of these more common reagents would be required.  Also, tests of different kinds that do not use PCR are being developed.

CDC's delay in the deployment of testing is unacceptable. It is more important to have a test running than to "re-invent the wheel" in times of emergency. The accuracy of a test is important, however, when compares to the urgency of a test when the virus is spreading fast, the choice is obvious. Let's hope that there will be a congressional inquiry when we are through this COVID-19 pandemic.

As a laboratory scientist, I feel that it's important to acknowledge the years that go into developing and validating laboratory tests. There's no point in rushing a test to the market only to find that it yields too many 'false positives' (a positive result when the person doesn't have the disease) or 'false negatives' (a negative result in a person who doesn't have the disease). Both can be devastating to a patient and misleading for public health investigations. 
This coronavirus is called 'novel' for a reason: we've never encountered it before (though we've seen organisms like it). While there are protocols in place to ramp up test development, these processes don't turn on a dime. They need time to be validated and implemented responsibly. The swab is then placed in a solution (viral transport media) in a plastic test tube which is capped and chilled and sent to the reference lab. One month ago, I could find no viral collection swabs or viral transport media to purchase anywhere, all supplies were back ordered at least 2 weeks from all suppliers - this is not "toilet paper," folks. Can N-90 masks, critical and in desperately short supply, be quickly disinfected and reused?  I think they can.

1.  Soak the masks for about 20 mins in 99% ethyl alcohol, (which can be bought by the gallon by any lab, if they do not have it already).   Alcohol at this concentration should quickly destroy the virus.
2. Remove the masks and the alcohol will evaporate quickly (has to be done in a well ventilated environment, no flames or sparks).
3.  The now-dry masks (with ventilation they should dry in under 30 mins) should be clean and ready for reuse.  

As good as a new N-90 mask?  Maybe not, but it is better than none.

We elected a fox. Ensconced him in the henhouse. But henhouse health wasn’t his jam. Not one bit. Only looking foxy mattered. Any hen that didn’t produce golden eggs—gone. Specialized hen teams—gone. Only the roosters who crowed with gusto about the fox’s greatness remained. 

One day, about three months ago, in a faraway land (a rival henhouse)—a huge natural disease struck. While hens of the world had seen diseases before, this one was new. Big. Scary. The fox secretly smiled. It made a competing fox’s numbers look bad. And all was “beautiful” said the fox. In fact the fox was gleeful. He got more and more time in front of the national mirror. Mirror, mirror on the wall—who’s the most beautiful of them all? “You,” said the only remaining hens and roosters. You. You. You they crowed dozens of times. 

The fox smiled. Yes, he noticed a few hens were dying. But that paled in comparison to This Great Moment of reality TV.

The sky is falling, said one hen. And she was correct. She was banished. 

Across the land roosters, hens, chicks and eggs were dying. 

Small henhouses thrummed day and night to save the hens. Efforts of remarkable proportion and selfless love.

The fox huffed and puffed and tried to blow the henhouse down.

In San Antonio Texas, we wait in line each day for around two hours in front of the grocery store.   A manager-- accompanied by an off duty policeman-- only lets small groups of us inside.  The grocery chain, HEB has had to place limits.

Will they have eggs this morning?  No.  

For all the social distancing, people stick together.  A woman leaves the store, shucking off blue nitrile gloves.  

"That's it.  They're out of eggs."

Three people leave the line.  

A man in calls out, "Cash only.  Card readers are down.  Whole city."

This news is confirmed by the manger outside.  Two people leave.  A woman becomes angry and distraught.  She starts yelling at the manager.  The policeman steps in. He seems compassionate as he tells her the store has two ATMs.  She leaves the line anyway.  No cash?

Inside the store, it feels creepy.  Where 80-100 people might be shopping, only 30 at a time.  A woman sneezes.

I think that will be the memory I will always carry from this pandemic.  People stop and stare.  The look on her face is...  Embarrassment?  Fear?  Terror?  Where can she get tested?  Where can any of us get tested?  

Another morning standing in line again, we ask one another: how did it come to this?

Presumably, this is an issue in the U.S. as well as abroad, and for the crews, I am not sure what is worse: being forced to continue to work beyond one's contract, or having to work with new crew mates upon reassignment, with no guarantees regarding whether anyone in the new crew has been exposed to coronavirus.  Unfortunately, given the acute shortage of COVID-19 test kits, testing crew members before they commence assignments working in close proximity with one another aboard a ship is probably not a realistic option.

Merchant Marines the US Sailors that operate in interstate and international waters can be drafted into duty, not unlike other branches of government and our armed forces. They receive compensation for doing so, and every Sailor knows the day might come when they will be called to serve.

Having sailed on merchant vessels for many year and then establishing a successful ship management company,  I feel it is likely many of the crew members understand the necessity of what they are doing and the reasons for the limited and / or delayed crew changes.

It makes sense to minimize the introduction of new personnel to uninfected ships, as any infection would be shared.  Seafarers absolutely understand this.

That said, orderly arrangements for repatriation and  safe crew changes must be made.  It remains the ship manager's obligation to observe the labor contracts agreed, the terms as mandated by national and international laws.  Bad actors are out there, and they will take advantage of the situation.  But the industry has worked quite hard to weed them out through procedures, laws and regulations that are enforced globally.

As soon as quarantine and travel bans are lifted that will allow the landing, transport and repatriation of seafarers, the crew changes will continue with all dispatch.  Everyone wants to be with and protect our families in time of danger. 

Nationality makes no difference.
They should at least be paid double time and allowed rest days every week.

Seems like there would be a way to have a safe compromise if the companies had a will to find it.

I am a college professor in Canada. Where possible, our classroom-based courses are now delivered online for the rest of the term. Our domestic students have been encouraged to go home but our international students who are in residence have been allowed to stay in residence. This is understandable - while they're encouraged to return home, they are worried about how online studying from their home country might impact their student visa status, and we cannot tell them definitively if their next semester (which we run from May to August) will be affected.  Some of them have only been here since January and they're still experiencing adjustment shocks to being in a different country with a very different culture. Besides all of this, I think it's inhumane to evict these foreign students from residence and onto the streets if they have nowhere else to go and no one here in this country to rely on. 

We shifted from classroom-based learning to online learning starting on March 16th. Earlier this afternoon, an email was sent from administration - we now have our first presumptive positive case on our campus, a student in residence. I imagine more cases will emerge. 

I wouldn't want to be a decision maker in the upper echelon of our college administration. Kicking students out of residence if they have nowhere to go is not palatable. But inviting *all* students back to campus like they're doing at Liberty University? That's asking for trouble...

The statistical models that are the basis of predictions around this pandemic or other pandemics are pretty straightforward - well covered ground. The details may be new, e.g., when does a person become infectious with this particular virus, how rapidly does it spread in different populations. But the underlying statistics are not new - and the predictions based on a few very reasonable assumptions related to human behaviour would have made it abundantly clear that to epidemiologists that what we are seeing was going to happen. 

Water under the bridge.  The question for me is: what are these same people saying about the next 6 or 12 months - when people start to resume more usual patterns of social interaction.  If we didn't listen to the epidemiologists back then, have we reflected upon the possibility that there is something they are telling us today that we aren't listening to.  E.g., if in 6 months we are not relying on social isolation and instead are employing contact tracing and testing - do we have testing capacity - even if we have enough to manage the current pandemic (which I do not think is the case).

Managing this outbreak - and the next infection after COVID-19 -- via a combination of ignoring the results of robust statistical models based on realistic assumptions, followed by acts of desperation - not a good way to manage outbreaks.  

So again- the past has passed. What are we ignoring today? And who should be listening - and are they?

The president wants to know: "How do you get from 20 to 40 to 300???"  He is talking about the thousands of masks needed in New York hospitals to fight the Coronavirus Pandemic. He implies that Gov. Cuomo is trying to pull a fast one.  The answer to his question is math.  The pandemic grows exponentially, which means by multiplication rather than by addition.  It's hard to visualize; but write the numbers in a list and you will be amazed.  Exponential growth means every data point is multiplied by two by the time you arrive at the next data point (in this case corresponding to the two people each one infected person infects-- 20 people infect 40).  Thus 20 doubles to 40, 40 doubles to 80, 80 doubles to 160, 160 doubles to 320, and so on.  If the doubling time is, say, 3 days (which it is right now), you get from 20,000 to 40,000 to 300,00 masks in about 12 days.  Add the numbers up and after 12 days your 20 has become 640.  In this matter, that refers to 640,00 masks needed within two weeks.  (If you ADDED only 20 every three days to your original 20 you'd be at 100, a number the president could presumably comprehend.)
 Try doing it 30 times, representing 90 days. You'll see why the Governors are pleading for help.

This SARS-CoV-2 virus specifically latches on to the ACE2 receptor while also using the TMPRSS2 gene to make its spike sticky so it can attach.  It then injects its RNA through the cell membrane to hijack the cell and replicate.

Researchers are looking at drugs to deny virus entry by filling in that ACE2 receptor notch and interfering with TMPRSS2.

Certainly among major industrialized countries, Japan must score last in terms of workforce flexibility and innovation as well as the oldest consumer market in the world.  Japanese industry, today, operates more or less as it has since the days of the bubble economy, with the stark exception that Japan no longer as the client base to support the models that they used when money was flowing freely.  Too often the most talented in Japan are held back thanks to a structure that rewards years of service rather than workplace excellence.  Additionally, the emphasis on extreme quality measures results in prohibitive costs for products that an older and income-challenged population find it hard (if not impossible) to meet.  For Japanese, the number of hours worked is still considered more important than the quality of the work done and herein lies the heart of the problem for the country. Evidently, Trump's understanding of ventilators is poor at best.  Usually, one ventilator is sufficient for one patient.  In emergency circumstances, the output can be split, and two patients can be supported by one ventilator, with specific caveats, such as the patients have to be well matched.  As an analogy, different tires may require different inflation pressures.  Splitting the output of an air pump to inflate two tires at once might work if the two tires need the same air pressure, and the pump has enough capacity.  If the tires need different pressures, say 30 pounds for one and 40 for the other, setting the pressure to 35 pounds gets you one overinflated tire and one underinflated tire. With humans, that could mean too much air for one, and too little for another, which is bad for both.

So Trump seems not to understand that two ventilators in a hospital means that the hospital will have a problem if three patients, all with different requirements, need to be provided with a ventilator.  But that does not stop him from making preposterous statements, or just plain lies.

Liberal thinkers have made of individual liberties the touchstone of political rectitude. However, the main internal constraint to these is that they can only be enjoyed in a safe environment... whereas any measure to secure public safety must infringe on those very liberties. This painful paradox is convincingly illustrated by the following metaphor. Threats to security originate either from others (theft, aggression, murder, rape...), or from oneself (carelessness, risky behaviour, excessive drinking, drug abuse...). 
Defense against the former is symbolized by the rampart, which protects you against other people by restricting their movements. Defense against the latter is symbolized by the guardrail, which prevents you from harming yourself, but at the cost of limiting your movements. Every rule or law designed to safeguard the members of a community are more or less abstract renderings of one of these physical realities. There can be no absolute freedom without insecurity... and no complete security without a contraction of personal freedom.
When a group of people feel safe, they wish to push back the restrictions to widen their margin of freedom. When they are threatened, on the opposite, they feel the need to pull them in, to increase their safety zone. So a socio-political regime cannot define personal freedom or public safety as absolutes, but should rather give itself a flexible and transparent mechanism to adjust them to any situation.

We are a largely single occupancy vehicle commuter town and off the cuff I would conservatively estimate at least half of our residence live in single family structures.  Compared to the NY subway and urban density these two cities are apples and oranges when it comes to transmission vectors.

Good information.  Thank you.  I have a question on word choice. We are all looking at better data from day to day and reassessing decisions.  We are all hopeful about returning to normalcy.  We know our president is not a word-smith. A footnote to this excellent article: I live with my 55 year old son, in Washington, on the North shore of the Columbia River. He has asthma. The information in this article is good news and important data. It disseminates what we can add to our knowledge of how to deal with this virus. As a physician, I look for any and all data on this new virus that I can find. I have lost patients to this infection and I have seen people recover. It is good news to learn that the transmissions per person might be down.  That news may be premature because the data available is still fairly small in spite of increased testing in King County.  Testing at UW hospital has been in the range of 2500 per day for three of the last four days, but dropped to 1500 yesterday.  For such small samples in King County, pop. 2 million, the range of uncertainty in the transmissions per person is large.  When the uncertainty in the data is factored in, it is not clear how much the transmission per has declined, if it has declined at all.  The percentage of tests returned positive to UW Hospital has been 9.5, 11.7,15.0,and 13.3 over the last four days, with the 13.3% on about half of the samples of the prior 3 days.  These numbers are not indicative of a decline, other than a decline in testing.  If testing is reduced because of fewer identified subjects to test, that would be good news.  The transmission numbers are in the right direction, which is good news, but we need two or three more days of data to confirm that there is indeed a trend.  The testing data needs to be complete enough to show the number of new cases traceable to a prior case.  But there are not enough tests to identify a substantial portion of existing cases yet.  The best advice is to continue hunkering down until the virus has conclusively been checked.

Seattle has been lucky. The infection has been spreading quietly in both Washington State as well as NY and CA since January. But Seattle was the first to act. Local companies like Amazon and Microsoft started working from home around March 4th, a good 10 days before NY. 

The reason for this is that one of the first places that was hit was the nursing home in Kirkland, which led to the first dozen or so deaths in the US. This vulnerable community showed the presence of the virus clearly and unambiguously, triggering a response. Local business and administrators acted immediately. 

In a sense, Seattle was lucky that the nursing home served as a canary in a coal mine. It caused us to start taking the virus seriously well before others did and gave us a headstart.  States that still have time to act should take note.

As much as this seems to be good news, I would like to see more analysis regarding the testing sample size. From the reporting here and elsewhere it is not clear to me that enough random people are tested to know how many folks are not showing symptoms  yet have the virus. What percentage of the total population needs to be tested to fine tune our growth rate analysis (or perhaps I am wrong and we now have accurate numbers)
That said keep up the great reporting, and keep the visibility on the governmental and private section actions and result of those actions. As always, a free press is a vital element to our health, culture, and survival.

There's only one answer here. Keep the restrictions in place and be willing to strengthen them if necessary. 

Some experts have floated the idea of using widespread surveillance and testing of individuals (as China had done and continues to do) as an option to a complete shutdown. But we do not, nor, realistically are we going to develop, this capability. Full stop.

We either maintain these lockdowns (and based on everything I've read they will really need to stay in place through the end of May, at a minimum), or we are going to be looking at a catastrophe the likes of which the vast majority of us cannot even imagine.

Wishing well to all those on the East coast!  As a Seattle resident, I have to say that this article is too soft on the local WA state government and Seattle leadership.  Keep in mind (with full hindsight) that the Puget Sound region had the FIRST COVID 19 case in the US, in late January, and Gov Inslee did not order any real "stay home" order until March 25th, 2 months later!  Seattle schools were resistant to closure initially, and the WA government chose to delay issuing any real stay-home order until weeks after other states.  Italy issued pleas to other countries to take drastic measures to slow the spread of the virus in early March, but no on really listened. Living just south of Seattle, in Portland metro, we followed many of the same recommendations of Seattle - a little later by a week perhaps - but from initial reports from several front line doctors we know, there seems to have been a significant flattening of the curve and a reduction in the expected rise and peak of transmissions at the hospitals where they work - yea! 

The point is that it is better to be over cautious and view this stay in place - and the data seems to be supporting that.  

Unfortunately not all states are taking it seriously and believe science can be trumped by belief or sheer will power of not wanting to catch it.  From the preliminary transmission tracking data that appears not to be a strategy worth following.   

We view this hibernation a little like the time between Thanksgiving and New Years (without all the shopping madness) where we hold up as a family and spend time cooking, exercising, watching movies, and completing items on the long list of house chores!  We have not been out in two weeks since our initial food purchase and since we have an earthquake preparedness kit - we are self sufficient for another two months.

This article is a good summary, but there are additional factors that may explain the slowdown here. I live in a university community. I am cautiously optimistic that our community is taking the right measures, but there was a hiccup at the beginning. When we had a single case that was connected to a traveler returning from Beijing who went from our local airport to the hospital, we instituted traveler screening at that time and just sat and waited for community spread. Feb. 5, the date the first case was isolated and travel screening started was marked as if it really had any scientific basis. We did not even suspect infected travelers who did not report to the hospital existed. This was a bizarre way of looking at our first case. Our public officials thought we were just lucky that the first case self-identified and showed up to be tested. I worried then, and have been proven correct, that case was just a single data point in the disease coming into our community. It was smoke indicating a fire was starting. We are a college town. It would be trivial to require the hospitals and health departments to report the basic demographics of the dead to a central database. Age, sex, underlying conditions, typed of residence, etc. Any grad student in public health could design this, and the computer power to analyze the basics is resident on a home computer. PS I used to work in hospital management. 

Suppose we remove all the nursing home residents, multiple immunosuppressant, morbidly obese, COPD, and a few other “walking dead” conditions from the data. How many deaths now, who are they, and what treatments did not work? That’s how we save people who are most likely to be saved. Darwinian reality and not PC, but it appears that most who died were already living on borrowed time. The good news is who has not died in droves. It's very hard to calculate an R0 without knowing the actual number of people who have the disease, which we still do not know. Local governments may take credit for evidence that the effects of the virus are showing signs of abating, but that may amount to taking credit where no credit is due.

Right now governments around the world are pursuing different strategies.  For example, Sweden and Japan have been pursuing more relaxed strategies.  It may very well be the case that all strategies yield the same results -- because the idea that the virus can be contained may be deeply flawed.  The virus may already be out there.   Even if it were not, it may still be impossible to contain.

Think about it.  The US may be spending $2.2 trillion to do little more than track a bad cold virus.  It would be great if we could spend a mere $10 million to randomly sample 10,000 New Yorkers and screen them for *antibodies*.  We may find that 40% or more of them have already had the virus.

There is a difference between satisfying a morbid curiosity and providing useful information.

Do you want your local television news reporter at your front door if someone in your home is positive for the coronavirus?  Do you want the New York Times to identify you as an infected patient?  Probably not, but maybe.  

At the same time, if a newly diagnosed person is suspected of being at a gathering where others may have attended, it may make sense to broadcast the fact that people who attended an event could have been exposed, and should be tested.

So, useful public information only, please.  And let the patient decide if he or she is going to be named in the news.

On the other hand, we have lived with mandatory reporting laws for decades.  Doctors must tell their state if a patient has tuberculosis, for example. Researchers who explore contact information for epidemiological purposes should be given the information they need.  They just need to be careful about protecting the privacy of individual patients.

The protocols for dealing with medical information are clear and well-established. Individual patient information is confidential and must remain that way. Aggregated information can and must be publicly communicated, especially in critical situations like the current pandemic.
Where information about individual cases is made public, it must be scrubbed of any details that might identify that person.
There is no reason to modify these procedures.

Two points - this article is wrong about HIPAA and people who have been in contact with someone should know who that person is. 

First, HIPAA was not designed in the era of paper records. I was an Information Security (INFOSEC) Specialist for the DoN (retiring in (2018). I inspected, tested, and accredited information systems throughout the Navy and Marine Corps, and, often, other components of the DoD and federal government. We started developing procedures and practices to meet HIPAA requirements even as final drafts were being completed. Our goal was to ensure any data contained in any information system, not just hospital systems was protected but hospital systems were focused on particularly because their systems were particularly sensitive and also largely outdated. Most contained obsolete hardware and software. Everywhere that was so, the systems were replaced at great cost. Where the systems were adequate, we locked them down. In both cases, we educated the people using them on how to do so. Most appalling, the medical community largely was unaware of HIPAA or its requirements. 

Second, very public people, such as members of Congress like Senator Rand Paul, have publicly announced their infections and committed to self-isolation. That was not for sympathy but to warn anyone that had shaken their hands, etc. If the most famous can admit they may have put others in danger, why shouldn't we all. We all affect thousands of others whether we know it or not.

With that objective in mind, we first formally examine strategies for controlling outbreaks by way of environmental stochastic-ities human institutions help set. Using the Data Rate Theorem, we next explore disease control regimens under asymmetric conflicts between agribusiness interests rich in resources and State public health agencies and local communities constrained by those very resources. Military theory describes surprising successes in the face of such an imbalance, a result we apply here. Abduction points to strategies by which public health can defeat agribusinesses in its efforts to control agriculture-led pandemics, the heavy health and fiscal costs of which multinationals routinely pass off to the public.

Comparing numbers in various countries or states can be useful --
but only if compared on a per capita basis --
or per thousand or per million population.

Comparing the number of cases (or deaths) in California to the total number in New Jersey is highly misleading unless the numbers are reported per capita -- or per thousand or per million. California has  twice the population of New York, four times the population of Michigan and nine times the population of Louisiana.

Likewise, comparing the number fo cases (or deaths)  in the USA to the total number in, say Germany, is highly misleading unless done on a per capita -- or per thousand or per million. The USA has four times Germany's population and nearly five times the population of the UK or France and more than five times the population of Italy.

1.  Soak the masks for about 20 mins in 99% ethyl alcohol, (which can be bought by the gallon by any lab, if they do not have it already).   Alcohol at this concentration should quickly destroy the virus.
2. Remove the masks and the alcohol will evaporate quickly (has to be done in a well ventilated environment, no flames or sparks).

Wearing a simple face mask has some value but it is very limited. The C-virus is not in the air as such, but in the minuscule water droplets that come out of your longs when you breath out (not many), cough (many more) and sneeze (a lot many more). A mask is only useful, if it can stop these water droplets. If it isn't very tight around your nose and mouth, it is not of much use, as the droplets will simply pass through the gaps as you breath in. If the water droplets touch your eyes, you can also be contaminated. That's why HC workers wear such face masks. Once you have used your mask in a compromised situation, you have to discard it and use another one. It is difficult, even next to impossible, to know when a situation is compromised, unless you are up close to known patients. A mask is somewhat useful if you have the C-virus, because it will stop some of the droplets when you sneeze or cough. But, then, you shouldn't be out and around people, in the first place ! Whenever you go out, the best thing to do is to stay 6 feet away from another person, refrain from touching your face and wash your hands, when you return home. Then relax and think about something else.

In Asia, many people have indeed worn for many years face-masks to counter air-pollution, but they are of no use - at all - since the pollution is in the air and you breath it in. At best, it will keep some dust out of your nostrils.

 “Crimson Contagion” was an influenza pandemic,  simulated by the Trump administration’s Department of Health and Human Services in a series of exercises that ran from January to August 2019.

We've provided grant writing consulting services for hundreds of nonprofits across America for 28 years. In economic crises like this, nonprofits should forgot seeking donations and they hold fundraisers. Instead, they need to immediately start writing foundation and government grant proposals. No other option or many will go under. Weepy articles like this are not helpful. Sorry for the grim news, but this is reality.

One of the biggest take aways from the history of philanthropy is that philanthropy cannot respond to national crisis. It wasn’t created to do that. Hoover tried to make that happen during the Great Depression and it failed and almost cashed out the major foundations (which may have been ok lol). He had to accept that the only option is federal intervention - just like now. That doesn’t mean nonprofits have no value. They are meaningful as a vehicle for private citizens to participate in civil society - by working in these orgs, giving to them and volunteering. The sector doesn’t actually have the scale or coordination to respond to major events. It never will.

Nonprofits and businesses with 500 employees or fewer should avoid layoffs and instead seek low-interest loans through the SBA which can convert to grants up to $2M if you keep your employees on payroll. These funds can be used for a wide range of working capital and debt service needs. Rely on your professional services providers, such as your CPAs who prepare your tax returns for specific advice, and spread the word!

At this very difficult time, how well nonprofits communicate with their stakeholders may be key to their survival. But with low budgets and often, no trained marketing and communications staff, this can be a major challenge. Here is a free guide to crisis communications for nonprofits: https://www.nonprofitmarketingbook.com/crisiscomms I hope this is helpful.

Here is our obligatory sad-but-true story of how unfair the world is where greedy corporations get even more money while worthwhile humanitarian efforts suffer, but it also contains a hint of the hazy future of American nonprofits. In the last 40 years, the number of small nonprofits has exploded while the middle class (who provide most of the donations) has been hollowed out and its wealth systematically transferred to those already wealthy. Couple that with systematic deconstruction of social safety nets by conservative governments and skyrocketing needs, and you have the recipe for the demise of many good nonprofits. There are simply fewer donation dollars chasing too many good causes. And the future doesn’t look bright, either. Will Millennials who are laden with debt be able to support good causes financially the way previous generations have? 

The point is this: If we want an America that is “kinder and gentler” we will have to change our spending priorities at both government and personal levels to support it, and those who start nonprofits have to pay more attention to building financial resilience and community support rather than putting every dollar to direct mission. Donors will have to cheerfully give to building capacity instead of designating for direct mission only.

Non-profits struggle because we have to pour resources into obtaining funding, pleasing donors, providing documentation for audits of every cent of minuscule government funding we fight to receive. All the while diligently maintaining that the vast, vast majority of that funding is going to direct services. While private companies are able to generously allocate funding to overhead costs - which enable an organization to succeed at its ultimate mission - non-profits must minimize overhead to ludicrously low levels in order to satisfy both individual and governmental grantors. It is an endless and thankless struggle.

The problem is not COVID-19, it is the way our government and our economy have been built to ignore the needs of the people in the pursuit of profit.

Over the decades I was administrator and later CEO of a range of small and very large nonprofits. Pre-retirement I was a board member of and planning/fundraising consultant to a similar range of nonprofits.

In the best of times small non-profits without endowments led a hand-to-mouth existence, struggling each year to meet payroll and program costs.

Even institutions with 7- or 8-figure endowments usually had to work hard to raise enough money to meet annual expenses. Institutions with budgets of 100 million plus maintained vast fund-raising staffs and efforts to keep the money coming in, some for operations, some to build endowments still further.

Coronavirus and its impact on the economy will devastate the poorer part of the non-profit spectrum, driving many out of business in a matter of months as attendance drops and donations dry up. 

Mid-size institutions can cut programs and staff to try to weather the storm until the economy stabilizes and then improves, whenever that might be.

Larger organizations can cut staff and programs and, if absolutely necessary, take the fraught step of dipping into endowment.

The flow of donations has already been truncated by the sharp financial downturn; previously generous supporters still don’t know how far their assets and incomes might drop in the months to come, so they are sitting on their checkbooks.

The worthiness and importance of nonprofits are not in question; the near- and long-term survival of these institutions is.

Most small nonprofits live hand to mouth and do not have endowments.

However, most nonprofit organizations with endowments have a mechanism that allows them to “borrow” from their own endowments to cover operating expenses. This process varies according to federal and state laws and institutional charters and by-laws, so consulting an experienced attorney is a must.

Of course such “self-loans” are approved by a nonprofit’s board of directors only in extreme emergencies because drawing down endowment reduces income from endowment, an erosion of a fiscal resource that cannot be continued indefinitely; it is generally considered bad practice and even unethical to deplete endowments in most cases.

Most of the very large non-profits in NYC have large or huge endowments, so they have internal financial resources they can use in emergencies like the coronavirus pandemic. 

However, channeling relief loans and grants only to the biggest and most successful institutions is rather like withholding ventilators and ICU beds from coronavirus patients over 60, or disabled, or with underlying conditions. 

This very serious medical issue is only now being discussed openly in the NYT and other media, so perhaps it is only fitting that we see the start of an open discussion of whether in this medical/financial crisis triage must be applied to select out the nonprofits least likely to survive.

I have read all of these comments carefully and would like to pivot to a more tactical (and practical) conversation.  

Non-profit organizations are struggling with if and how to fundraise during this unprecedented crisis.  The answer is that they must fundraise.  Many - if not most - non-profits rely upon a combination of contributed and earned revenue (think tuition, ticket sales, counseling fees, etc)

For most of my clients and the many,  many non-profits I have spoken with over the past couple of weeks, earned revenue has essentially dried up.  At the same time, many continue to provide services, in particular to vulnerable populations whose needs have exploded.  

The best advice I can give non-profits is to utilize your board  more than ever to make your case with your most loyal donors, and for the board, itself, to give generously.

The U.S. is unlike any other country in our reliance upon and support of non-profit organizations.  I strongly encourage NYTimes readers to give to the organizations of your choice to the best of your abilities.

The parents should self-isolate, which means "son move in and stay in, or stay out for the duration."  They do not help him by enabling his thoughtlessness.  They put themselves at risk, especially since his roommates may share his nonchalant attitude.  

I miss my kids and grand kids terribly, but we text and FaceTime and call almost daily. I don't want them to have the guilt that would come with making me sick, and I don't want to make them sick, either.  The only way to be safe is to stay away from people, until we have an extended period of no new cases.  Or a vaccine, which seems presently unlikely.

The free-loading son is a health security risk.  Either he’s in for the duration, or he is out.  No in between.  If he’s in, he needs to be part of the household and contributing where he can. And no running out to gather with friends!

The decision needs to be made now.  More and more people are being infected.  And if he is in, he should probably self-quarantine in the house.

It really stinks, but the parents’ health is jeopardized by the indecision.  My elderly mother is effectively quarantined in her continuing care facility.  My young sons miss her, and she them.  I do, too!   But we know it is the right thing to do.

The advice for the freeloading son is part of the problem. The way to solve the problem is to change the locks (if permitted where they live.) No physical contact. No free meals. No free laundry. 25-year-old men are capable of taking care of themselves.

I like that part of the first answer about Americans being out of practice when it comes to sacrifice for the greater good. At first, I thought: that can’t be true. But I can’t come up with a strong example. Not since the Great Generation have Americans been asked to give up something for the greater good. And it shows in the selfishness of many about social distancing.

Wow, the author is SO OFF making excuses for the freeloader.  I am a physician in an urgent care center in suburban Miami.  I work with an amazing team of mainly under 30 medical assistants and X-ray techs who don't freeload off their parents, have a fantastic work ethic and most are in school or improving their lives in some way.  These people are in no way from privileged backgrounds.  I cannot understand why anyone would need to make excuses based on age.  Think about this, millennials are not any different than any other generation, what you are seeing are immature young adults that are the minority in their generation, and most 25 year olds are actually quite responsible and reasonable.  By the way, the freeloader's parents, should just announce the free ride is over, if they only could.

"Being 25 is harder than when we were young." ??? When was that?  I am a forensic genealogist and am immersed daily in census records from 1900-1940. It was not uncommon to see 14 year old boys as the breadwinner in a fatherless household. Even in my generation (Okay Boomer!), a 25 year old may have fought in Viet Nam or was at least a father out working to support children. As a 25 year old woman, I had put myself through college and supported myself since 18. I bought my first home at 27. That was during a recession. The parents in the letter raised a failed adult and the key is the statement "we do everything for him." I wouldn't let him in the house at all, but they have obviously catered to him his entire life in an effort to be loved.
Someone said “there are no bad children,only bad parents.”

Tough love in the time of Corona:  Report him and his reckless friends to the police for flouting quarantine laws.  Give him a warning beforehand that you will do this and see if he changes his behaviour.  He will not and laugh it off, of course - that's when you report him to the authorities.  Before all this, heed the advice of others here, and make sure he doesn't step foot in your house any longer while the pandemic is raging on.

"For those who can afford to make more than suggested donations to small businesses you value: Now is the time! We really are all in this together."

I just texted the woman who cuts my hair to ask if she needs me to pay in advance for my next haircut.

Regarding restaurant meals:
You can't ask him to share while he's eating it, but you can stay after he's left. "No, you go on ahead, I've got to XYZ." Once he's gone, he doesn't have any say. You should respect him while he's there, but you don't have to respect silly, wasteful behavior when he leaves. Once he abandons something, he has no say over what anyone does with it. The restaurant is just going to throw the food away. Waste not, want not.  This is why cops can take fingerprints off abandoned water glasses.

Fair game. 

Online Yoga Classes:
Contact the studio and suggest that you might pay a moderate monthly fee that you could afford? Even $25 or $30 would probably go a long way to helping them make ends meet during the pandemic. They are undoubtedly paying increased overhead for folks using their services. Make a donation once a week that amounts to a monthly fee. But don't assume that because something is payment-optional that you can be a deadbeat. If you can't pay, don't use the service. You don't NEED it. You WANT it. There's a difference between needs and wants. 

Failed to Launch Son:
I have a 25 year old son who lives with me. Due to mental illness, he may never launch. It is somewhat, but not much, harder than when we were young. I graduated during the Bush I recession, after all. No jobs then either! He does his own laundry. He helps with chores. He goes to school. I pay for groceries, but he helps shop. 

Good boundaries are key. I set them. I am the adult.

LW with the friend who won't share: Perhaps stop eating out with her, given that she's a food-waster.

If you're up for it, please explain to her that wasting food is one of the worst things a person can do. It wastes raw materials, plus the energy used to harvest / transport / cook it, plus all the energy (heat/AC, lights) at all the facilities where that happens. Roughly 40% of all food in America is wasted -- completely unconscionable at a time of extreme pollution and a climate crisis caused by massive waste of energy, and completely unconscionable bc it's a relatively easy thing to correct.

If she were to take home what she doesn't eat and use it for her next lunch, she'd avoid using using additional food or energy to create the lunch (apart from a little microwaving, maybe).

And perhaps tell her, bc she sounds like someone who doesn't pay attention to this stuff, that Americans use about 3-4x as much energy as Europeans, whose standard of living is just as high. Our per capital usage coupled with our huge population = catastrophe.  We also pollute far more.  She needs to get with it.
Being 25 is difficult.  That was great advice.  Give him a break.  Maybe he's not sure how to do laundry!

It sounds like letter writer #1 just doesn't like his son.  I don't see how bringing laundry home and eating with family is something you can barely deal with.  Are you just not happy to spend time with him? You subscribe the worst motivations to him but continue to have dinner with him.  Maybe he needs a break from his hectic home life?  He's not living with you and expecting you to take of him, correct?  How is a 25 year old supposed to live?  I can't believe you look down on him for having roommates.  At the same time you are so judgmental of him, you don't seem to be able to draw the line when there is a life threatening virus in the world.  If you don't like him, don't martyr yourself anymore and don't see him anymore.

"Son, we can't take the risk of getting sick and adding to our over-burdened healthcare system. So you are going to have to stay away for the duration, because you are not practicing social distancing. That means until the worst is over, no visits home for laundry, meals, or anything. We'll see you after the pandemic has abated. Meanwhile, we can stay in touch by phone, text or Zoom. Lots of love, mom and dad."

Re:  Freeloading son.  This comment is for Philip Galanes.  Your response to the father concerned about his 25 yr old son's muching is outstanding---especially the third and fourth paragraphs.  

We all will benefit from getting into better shape by making personal sacrifices in exercising our muscles for the greater good, especially now with so many the uncertainties ahead of usbecause of the Covid-19 pandemic.   Well said, Philip!
Online yoga classes: email the yoga class leader to run ads during the presentation in-between position changes. Jack Lalanne made it work for years. Deep breaths anybody?

Yoga student: You should send the $5. Your yoga studio also does not know what is coming next. They may be forced to close permanently. I’m guessing in person classes were much more than $5, and you were willing to pay for them. I get it, we are all anxious. But I promise, $5 here and there is not going to break you. If you’re not willing to pay, get out out your mat & create your own routine. Or find a you-tube video which gets paid by ads.

‘Why keep pressing on? You asked; she answered...
Badgering people is wrong. ‘

We should all take this to heart.  What a great way to sum up a life lesson.  

I too need to remind myself to pay attention and not to cross this line. 

Thank you for this succinct reminder.

For the person who thinks her friend should split meals or share, you need to respect the friend's views and leave her alone.  You risk her declining invitations to future meals.  I have always felt food is something that carries the potential to share disease.  When in high school I took to heart the idea of never sharing, I avoided the mononucleosis that seemed to plague my contemporaries that shared soft drinks at social occasions produced. Also, the friend might not share the same interest in your food choices and were prefer to make their own choices, no matter how small or large.  The more I think about it, your demands are downright rude by expecting to share. I would be looking for new friends.

Many years ago, (I am 81 now) when my life was in flux, I asked a relative if I could stay with her "for a short time" until my circumstances improved.

She said "No," which catapulted me into facing my situation and making decisions sooner rather than later.  It was a gift that keeps on giving.  It is quite amazing how exigency can clarify and enable responsibility.

The ethicist lost me when he started preaching on the tough life of a 25 year old who does what? mooches of his family and expects them to do his laundry whilst he has been out shaking his groove thang during the pandemic. Now is the time he needs to learn to do laundry and fix a meal. And wash his hands, I’m guessing he needs the reminder .

255 is still very young for mature decision making. The brain doesn't stop developing for another year. And to those of you who complain about the son and say "When *I* was his age ... " - did you walk to school on cold days with a potato between your mittens, too?

Sounds like junior is trying to get his inheritance a little early. Tell him he has to stay away until the pandemic is over and that he is putting lives, especially yours, in danger every time goes out and you will not be one of his victims.

If your son is not follow the recommendations of avoiding gatherings and self distancing, don't let him in the house.  He's an adult and should be able to follow simple rules.  Letting him in is a potential exposure of you and your spouse to the virus.  It's time for some tough love to help this adult start acting like one.

I am often puzzled by helicopter parents or the newly christened bulldozer parents who still treat their adult children as if they were young teenagers.

So your son comes to visit for a free dinner and to drop off his dirty laundry and you are actually asking advice on how to deal with that juvenile behavior?  Seriously?

If you want to find a root factor in the way your son treats you look in the mirror.  It's your house!  Set rules, and if he doesn't respect or abide by them, withdraw the dinner invite.  He can find another way to clean his clothes.

If he hasn't "launched" yet it might be because he is still being treated as a child.

I’m a single mom, only my son and I all along . After struggling in college and ended up dropping off I had to set the rules . He was working small job here and there and partying too much . At 25,  had enough , time for him to go. I was paying the rent and doing his laundry at this point. When I told my friend about letting him go, she said I would regret that because he seemed like he couldn’t take care or not ready to care for himself ! I did it anyway ! ( tough love). Now at 28( soon to be 29), he has his own apartment that he shared with his girlfriend, and they seem happy! He thanked me for helping him to be brave to navigate life in his own. I couldn’t be more proud of him and I like that I’m allowed to visit anytime I want ! Proud of my decision and more proud of my son ! There , I listen to my guts , didn’t ask advice or listen to bystanders ! Phew !

Sorry, the advice was way off the mark on restaurant meals.  I agree with the writer on food sharing.  A person who not only will not share with someone they (at least pretend) to like sufficiently to eat with, but then also refuses to save any uneaten food is just a pig.  Today there are thousands of people who really need the food this person apparently just wants to throw away.  Wasteful, self obsessed, oblivious to others....  I could go on and on....

So important!   I can’t wait to see the reams of kindness stories complied when this is over.  Out of tragedy may come a new perspective around the globe.  We are ALL one.   I cried when I saw all the people of a very poor apartment complex in Mumbai come out on their balconies and clap in unison.  God bless us, each and every one.

These are all true.

But it would also be nice if we had reports on how many test kits are created each day.  How many tests are then performed on those kits.  Same for ventilators and PPE.  Body counts and infection counts are important, but so is telling the world about our progress, who is making the progress so they get credit, etc.

There is kindness in this world. It’s all around us and now more than ever, we need more stories like this one to get us through this very difficult time.  Acts of kindness like a smile, a thank you,  donating to a food pantry or giving blood at your local Res Cross, every little bit helps.  Let’s be kind. We are all in this together and we will come through this together.

Let's talk overwhelming. It's one thing to deal with a pandemic, but here in Salt Lake, we're also dealing with plenty of seismic activity. I know we need to stay positive, but when aftershocks of magnitude 3 to 4 shoot through the city a few times per day, staying positive is extremely difficult. My body is pumping with adrenaline all day long, I have no appetite, and I can't go anywhere. In the last week, I've had to duck and cover about three different times due to the earth bouncing around like a trampoline. I apologize for the negative post on an article designed to help people stay positive, but staying positive is easier said than done, especially when issues compound. The world didn't stop, we did.

Another good news that somehow hasn’t gotten traction, is that the FDA on March 22 sent a letter to all healthcare providers (https://www.fda.gov/medical-devices/letters-health-care-providers/ventilator-supply-mitigation-strategies-letter-health-care-providers) instructing them to use commonly used CPAP machines (used to treat sleep apnea at home) for some mild cases, to prevent them turning into more serious cases that then need to go to the hospital. Yes, it is known that CPAP usage would aerosolize the virus which would then infect anyone near by. But this virus is so infectious we can assume everyone in the household of an infected person will be infected anyway. If using CPAP machines can prevent even a small number of patients from crowding our hospitals even more, then it’s worth trying. To be clear, this came from the FDA, so Drs reading this don’t dismiss it out of hand before actually reading the letter.

There is certainly opportunity for all of us to do good, even from our isolated couches.
If you are among the fortunate individuals who are financially solvent and not facing job loss in the near future, please consider donating your $1200 bailout to food banks or charities. 
My wife and I are middle-class teachers, working on-line with our students, and while $1200 is nothing to sneeze at, it won't make that much difference to our finances. In short, we're fairly secure.
Those who are now jobless and facing financial ruin desperately need help. We may disagree with a number of aspects of this huge bailout, but at minimum, when our funds arrive, we will donate them to those who are in desperate need.
John Donne said it best. "No man is an Island, entire of it self; every man is a piece of the Continent, a part of the main." Kindness is only a start, but we have to start somewhere.

There are so many things people can do from home besides - or after - a Netflix binge. Focus on these may help us feel less useless in the wider effort. For instance, there are a lot of citizen science projects out there you can contribute to from your backyard or just sitting in front of your computer: https://mashable.com/2016/08/12/citizen-science-wildlife-nature/ https://www.nationalgeographic.com/news/2015/1/150114-crowdsourcing-science-animals-wildlife-conservation-technology-citizens/#close

I agree with Mr. Ortman.  After four cancer surgeries and being over the age of 60, I am one of those people who has been changed.  I used to be the optimistic pessimist, in the sense that no matter how bad things are, they can always get worse.  In the case of COVID, that is likely true, but I have changed in the sense that when all one has to keep them going is a sense of hope, one begins to really appreciate the little things.  We have water, we have electricity, we have a bathroom.  The things we take for granted are now things for which we need to recognize and express gratitude.  I know, my husband of 30 years who is now working from home full-time can't believe it either.  My mother, who died of ovarian cancer in 2009 said, "Cancer changes a person."  This is not just a health issue, but a major upheaval of our social system.  We will all be changed by this experience.

Even with a truly awful response from the White House, we will get through this pandemic. Many lives will be lost, and there will be so much suffering, but we will learn and embrace what we haven't lost. I hope there will be a renewed interest in science, facts, education and reasoning through discourse. Those are the things that are going to get us out of this, not Donald Trump's gut feelings (which really are embarrassing, to him most of all). So to anyone who thinks higher education is bad for the country, I suggest that you take a look at what is happening.

Thank you Maria Cramer for writing this article. 

It will continue to serve a useful and wonderful purpose and reminder when my brain and emotions become overwhelmed with such dire and frightening statistics and information.

It is crucial to remember the key four areas you listed:

1) Kindness is being celebrated

2) Doctors and health workers are improvising and collaborating, and industries are trying to help.

3) Research on a vaccine and anti-viral treatment is moving at a breakneck speed.

4) The crisis holds lessons for the future.

Your article did not merely make me feel calmer and more hopeful, but it also served as a reminder to be kind and kinder to others.  

Sometimes a simple smile can work wonders.  While I was in a grocery line the other day, the lady ahead of me asked the cashier for some extra "Monopoly tickets" for the in-store game being played.  While the cashier was unable to do that, I told the lady I would give her mine since I live "Monopoly" every day, I don't need to play it too.  She was so tickled that I offered her my tickets.

Again - it's the little things, the little kindnesses that can go such a long way in making someone else, a total stranger, feel good, if even for a moment.

These days I'll take all the little moments I can muster and try my best to return the favor any way I can.

Great article, but the last paragraph recommends, "stay home if you are sick." This will never be practical until every American worker is afforded sick pay. Sick pay is no longer luxury for the well off, it's imperative for us all - ESPECIALLY for those who work in hospitality and are preparing and delivering our food.
Another bright spot: The tanking of the economy might ruin Trump’s chances for reelection!

It is hard to face the reality that our president and cohorts are more interested in corporate bailouts than the life of of our fellow citizens.  The USA is way behind the curve here.... the fault lies with our ignorant, blustering, self centered president.  I am quarantined in Germany (one month so far and who knows when it will be over?) .  The governments services are amazing: free tests to anyone who wants one; food deliveries, drug stores that deliver the medicine to your home (ring the bell and leave) etc.  We even had a doctor make 2 house calls here for an elderly man who has bronchitis!  And, it was not expensive!  Wake up, America!  Our president's bombast is not leadership!   Don't know when I'll be able to fly home...but meanwhile I am being sheltered by the kind Germans.

You could also our fitness is going to improve.  I just drove home and I have never, in my life, seen so many people out walking, walking the dog, biking, running, jogging, working in their yards. And you could add doing webex exercising and yoga.  As much as I am stress eating, my pants are getting loose.

Now last few days it is sunny and springlike weather, I walk in my neighborhood, to cover the whole area, it is a little more than a mile. 
So as I walk so many are out some walk some runs most I know and we talk keeping 6 ft plus distance, and then go on in our ways. 

This is so new because I see more than normal days when people are out to work and come home for their daily chores.

The environment is benefitting from the decline in industry and burning of fossil fuels. Our public natural spaces get a break from human traffic (and resulting degradation). I worry that animals might nest, give birth or den in areas too close to areas that with fill with people when normalcy returns, though. Seals might establish new rookeries in closed beaches. I guess we’ll deal with that when it happens. Glad to give Nature a break.
You left out the just, if extreme, vengeance of the Pangolin.
And Mother Earth gets a long-overdue breather.

Another bright spot is that the air is pure and the sky has reverted to its primordial blue, at least here in London. It’s a wonder to see, and paradoxical that a virus that attacks the lungs has made the air breathable. I dread the smog building up again on the London skyline as things return to normal. We'll soon enough be back to wrecking our air and destroying the lungs of our children with less discrimination than Mother Nature.

Kindness is a free gift we all have!  Like many others, I'm angry, frustrated and feeling ineffective in the face of Covid 19.  I saw a piece about an elderly lady playing her cello daily on her porch and it gave me the lift and shove my mother would have, if she were still in this world.
There is an inherent goodness in all of us! It's up to us whether we seek out that goodness or mire ourselves in the swamp.  Hope floats to the surface, if we let it.
Everyone has a gift or talent they can share, all we have to do is look for it and share it.  The effects of kindness whether anonymous or not, are immediate and returned in abundance.  
Thank you Maria for reminding us of that!
All things human have an afterward, / when we judge the / passions that we’ve stirred; / every wound leaves a scar / for the people who are / unable to unhear what they’ve heard.

Excellent and uplifting. 

Thank God this might help us prepare for a really really deadly pandemic or biological war by a rogue nation or terror group or suicidal religious group trying to hasten Armageddon.

Let us immediately prepare and use this for formative evaluation and modeling research and technology to learn and be ready for a yet worse pandemic outbreak.

This article was just exactly what I needed tonight to remind me to look on the bright side. After hearing of nine suicides within a 24 hour period in my county, it was devastating to hear about the detrimental aspects to mental health of COVID-19. I anticipated as such, but not quite so soon. We must stay positive, be supportive and kind to each other. Don't be hard on yourself, give yourself a break, do what you can daily to make it through the day. Reach out and stay connected to friends and loved ones. If you are able, do something for your local charities or community, check in on neighbors. Everyone, hang in there. I sincerely hope we can all get through this, together.

Here is a kindness some might consider: When those government checks are issued, be sure you really, really need yours more than someone you know who is now barely surviving.  For those who have enough money to survive, cashing that check and handing it to some single mother with no job would be an enormous gift.
I would have no problem if the Times exponentially increased its output of these kinds of articles! These stories are as important as it gets.

I turn this over to the great Wendell Berry. 

Look It Over

I leave behind even
my walking stick. My knife
is in my pocket, but that
I have forgot. I bring
no car, no cell phone,
no computer, no camera,
no CD player, no fax, no
TV, not even a book. I go
into the woods. I sit on
a log provided at no cost.
It is the earth I've come to,
the earth itself, sadly
abused by the stupidity
only humans are capable of
but, as ever, itself. Free.
A bargain! Get it while it lasts.

The NYT should bear in mind the power of highlighting good news such as this more prominently. It could encourage folks to continue with social distancing measures.

Think of it like a dieting analogy—if you try a diet and do not get results after a certain amount of time then you’re apt to give up on that diet. 

Have you considered whether the barrage of headlines focused on our impending doom can be harmful after a certain point?
Thanks so much for compiling this.  Please make this an ongoingly-updated feature.  We are going to need regular infusions of silver linings as we go through this.

Your discussion of vaccine preparation is especially encouraging. 

America, in coping with the incredible gobbledygook coming from Trump's mouth, is being deprived of he news about our scientists' efforts.

I thank them and wish them God's Speed.

Stores are the real culprits here. Stores did not implement limits on paper products-particularly Toilet Paper: They simply did not care as long as the product was purchased, Greedy people bought as much as their SUV's Trucks and Trailers could hold. Only now are stores putting up signs limited purchases- yet many still cannot get shelves restocked: Capitalism and Consumerism at its worst.

It’s ironic that there are no armed guards protecting the recently agreed on $2 trillion. Apparently if you’re dressed in sheep’s clothing you can be trusted.
On the other end of the scale, god forbid someone should get greedy in a supermarket.
I don’t agree with greed on either end of the spectrum but don’t be heavy handed with one but not with the other.

As a nurse who starts work at 6am I am still trying to figure out how to get TP in a month if needed. ( I have not gone to a store)  I can't go to a store that early bc here in Daytona Beach they are not open, and I have no idea of delivery if it matches my days off.  I called and offered to pay in advance so I can pick up but was declined from Publix.  So I know I have healthcare to worry about, but this really makes no sense of this fear due to holding.

I still don't understand why consumers decided on toilet paper to hoard. Of all things. And, why was it the first thing to disappear from shelves? After all, lots of other things can be substituted for TP. At my local stores, there are still plenty of paper towels and kleenex. There are baby wipes. Any of these things can be used for the same purpose. So, why are people crazy over toilet paper? The other things missing at my store are kitty litter, peanut butter and flour. I figure everyone is at  home with the cat making peanut butter cookies and rearranging the garage to accommodate hundreds of rolls of toilet paper. Crazy times.

When I heard that my fellow Tennesseans were lined up at gun shops, I told a friend 'They're coming for our toilet paper.' 

Doesn't seem like a joke anymore.
So what is being done with the 3-D printers in the US?

As much as I may try to stay positive and strong, I can't help thinking about the worst that could happen. I've already heard some observers say unthinkable words: "a year or two." What happens when people are out of work and destitute, there are not enough supplies on the shelves and they can't afford them, anger and frustration lead to theft and violence, the military is called out, the entire country starts to look like a horror movie, "World War Z," "28 Days Later," "Night of the Living Dead"? (At least in this last one, they move slowly - "Kill the brain and you kill the ghoul.") It's really difficult not to imagine things spiraling out of control, when an incompetent ghoul sits at the head of our government.

IN most  other places, from Greece to Afghanistan, there aren't toilets, as we know them. They are holes in the ground, some with a platform of sorts.  Hoses and/or  watering cans (called aftabas)  are used instead of toilet paper. 
So..stock up on watering cans, before they too are gone from the shelves.

So many terrific stories about people stepping up to help each other out during uncertain times - these are the ones that help to reinforce my faith in human beings. But we need so many more of those kinds of stories to outbalance the ones about people trying to benefit financially from the pandemic, or about people fighting over toilet paper.

At a local store last Friday, there was no TP. I'd heard that was a thing, but I was sort of stunned to see the empty shelves. What really surprised me was the woman in the check out line in front of me. 17 loaves of sliced white bread, and 13 packages of hotdogs (All that were in the store)> After she'd left, I asked the check out lady why anyone would need 17 loaves of bread, and 13 pkgs of hotdogs. "So no one else gets them" was her easy response.

I haven't had trouble procuring TP. I also have avoided big box stores like (no pun intended) the plague. Support your local mom and pop shops and you will be surprised to find the essentials you need oftentimes in abundance.

Bought a sleeve of washcloths they actually do a much better job in the effected areas. What was used before toilet paper?
Use your head folks. “Make do”:like great great grandma did.

I started online dating a few months before this started. I met a few dates in person that didn’t go anywhere. 

16 days or so ago I connected with someone and we started chatting on the phone in hopes of meeting soon. Needless to say we couldn’t meet in person, but we still talk every day by phone. It’s a wonderful way to get to know someone. I have something to look forward to every day and I look forward to meeting him in person one day.

You would think that making a baby during a pandemic would be inadvisable, a terrible idea, really. It’s one thing to have a baby boom after a blackout, it’s quite another when we can’t predict the path of this virus. 

Hospitals and medical providers being pushed to the brink, our system is under such stress. We are just at the beginning.

If not avoiding pregnancy for others, then for yourself and your potentially growing family. Exposing yourself, your baby, and others to this virus for pregnancy and wellness checks? I’d think twice.
I think that there should be PSAs strongly urging birth control at this time.  To bring a baby into this unknown and terrifying situation is beyond understanding.

The lockdown and quarantine measures would force people to make a choice on what truly matters. It may turn good for some and not so good for others. Humans are biologically wired to be wandering nomads, moving places to places to collect experiences and memories. Corona changed all that. The repercussions have only started and would still not be over in the coming weeks or months.

With my wife trying to teach special ed students by phone and Zoom, and me trying to do my engineering work as normally as possible, I am very grateful to have a basement and 1/4 acre yard.  If we were back in our 10x56 house trailer with a baby and a big dog, it might not go so smoothly.

After my ex (28f) and I (34m) split up six months ago, she moved into an apartment with many roommates. I live alone.

Since the crisis, she humbly asked me if she could stay with me, as she said a couple of the roommates were being reckless with the situation. I hesitantly said yes, and we have been mostly okay the past two weeks. In times like this there are things are more important than what led to us breaking up. 

Hopefully no babies come out of it, though.
I'm lucky to live my old ball and chain, but I'm beyond thankful there is another bedroom in the house for some time alone.

So glad I met a new man on match.com in December. We decided to be in each other's closest circles and it is wonderful to have almost forced intimacy.  It would have been absolute torture with my ex-husband! I'm 55 and he's 65!

I was happily single before Covid 19.  I'm more happily single now.  :-)

I do miss the weekly treks to my favorite club for dancing and socializing with friends, though.  :-(

My heart goes out to everyone stuck with someone they don’t love, or worse, stuck with someone abusive. Awful. I’m ever more appreciative to have a good partner during this quarantine. We try to give each other space. And when things get tense we both try to have “quick repair,” that is: make a sincere apology, affirm our love, and move on. We will all *really* know the kind of partner we have when this is over. If someone was consistently unkind, impatient, or cruel... get that covidivorce. As we are all learning, life is too short.

The pandemic presents hardships for parents and children obliged by court order to engage in visitations, sometimes requiring travel out of the area or state, often from households blended 2 or 3 times over (kids & other relatives or housemates going back and forth amongst multiple residences, schools, and so on).  Supervised visits in facilities that do not provide the 6’ per person distance needed to maintain public and personal health, with multiple kids of different ages and ability to self-control and from entirely different households families and cities. Some families have other members who are immunocompromised or else have other vulnerabilities, and some are in the habit of ignoring or may not be aware of the various and ever increasing list of possible coronavirus 19 symptoms. Kids may have to travel in small spaces of cars with people who may have been exposed and shedding virus, or the kids themselves could be that person. Some parents may lack authorization for making medical decisions for children or might send kids with uncleaned clothing or toys or other things that present contamination risk. Most kids in these situations are not venturing out to provide essential care for someone or otherwise doing an essential job, and the people whose job is supervising visitations are also at risk. Still, upsetting for parent and kid to have to skip time together. But maybe that’s better than one of them / their or the other household catching/spreading covid19 and dying.
My wife and I have lived together since we were 19.  We are now 41.  We joke that we have trained for this.
It is but a truism that times of crisis bring out the best in us. History has taught us that for the most part it is quite the other way around.

As the pandemic began I was trying to adjust to being alone after the the death of my husband last month. What helped was being busy - going to my office each morning - working all day and meeting friends for dinner.   I was looking forward to joining a bereavement group in early April.  
Now my new normal is working from my dining room table - preparing meals and walking my dogs.
I am not sure if this a good way to be grieving - alone in a house filled with memories but I have no choice. 
I have been fortunate to have a circle of friends and family that check on me everyday and listen to me talk with no advice or judgement.
This is my corona virus story - thankful my husband died in February in hospice and I was allowed to be with him until his last moments.

My husband and I purchased a big old house in rural GA two years ago and moved here permanently last November.  We feel we have the perfect place for social distancing - 4 acres, endless home projects, good weather for gardening and 4700 sq ft of house when we get tired of each other's company!  Sending good wishes to those stuck inside.  Be well.

Having the same incredibly stressful experience of still living under the same roof with my 30-year spouse from whom I'm "separated" and currently divorcing. I am not sick and neither is he. 

I get out once a day with the dogs, the only respite I have to get away from the dreadful darkness that is our former marriage. We have a 2-storey house but I am self-isolating in one room to stay away from him. I eat, sleep, watch TV, talk to friends all in this self-imposed house arrest. 

I run into him in the kitchen a few times a day, never a pleasant encounter. We often yell at each other, our resentments spilling over. There is almost no moment of civility. Having to see him every day is a cruel joke. I'm moving out in early May and can only focus on that. Getting away from this stressful living arrangement is a salvation I can almost grasp. 

Couples in troubled marriages will find clarity through this. Spend another minute with the guy lying on the couch in his tattered bathrobe? Nope. Time to move on, happy to live a new life, no matter the global crisis.
